title: All the places I have lived in
name: All the places I have lived in

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.24877,1.0287 My Current Home
properties.description: Posted by Ma77yChartham has two housing estates, one primary school (very good), three pubs (one in each corner of the settlement), a smattering of general stores here and there and a post office. We are also fortunate to have some of the most fantastic walks, views and countryside in this part of kent. Chartham is close enough to Canterbury for a night out but far enough away for the night out to not follow you home. By this I mean you can go out and enjoy yourself, get a cab home (because there are no trains into the village from Canterbury past 10pm), and go to bed without having to listen to everyone else on thier way home, vomiting on your doorstep as they pass.

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.31834,-0.23474 My Long Term Family Home
properties.description: Posted by Ma77y Seriously cool place to grow up. Acres of space to play e.g. on the race course or in the surrounding woods. Some great schools in the area and friendly people (in general). Even better than this though is the fact that you are still only 40 mins to 1 hour away from central London by train and not much more that that by car. The area come to a standstill for the first week in June when the Epsom Derby (the most important horse race of the English season), takes place. This is a great day out even if you are not in a gambling mood. The atmosphere is great. A bonus is that the three pubs that surround the course The Derby Arms, The Rubbing House and The Tattenham Corner are all well run and the food is of a good standard in all of them. Personally I prefer the Derby Arms. The food costs more but the quality is there to support it.

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.40389,-0.0003 My Wife and I's first flat
properties.description: Posted by Ma77yBromly is a great town which is more like an affluent suburb of London. Bars, shops, clubs cinema, swimming pools, all of which you would find in most large towns, but done at a slightly grander scale (due to the massive ammounts of council tax the residents pay). The is a fantastic mexican resturant quite close to the cinema and a great belgian returant underneath (and to the rear of) the Glades Shopping centre. The Beligian place is called L\'Abbye and it rocks. Shortlands is really only a place because there is a train station there and it is quite a steep walk up into the main town of Bromley. Again Bromley is quite middle class and the population a little elderly, but the town itself is great for weekend nights out. I particularly recomend "The Partridge", as a pub to go out drinking in but also for food during the day. The pub seems to be a converted Bank or something and the interior is quite impressive.

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.45443,-0.00217 Our First House
properties.description: Posted by Ma77yLIving here was great. The rail connection into London Bridge staion takes only 12 - 13 minutes (on a fast train) and not only that but all around the staion is a parade of shops which would make some villages blush. A good pub is the centre of this community and not only that there are two newsagents, at least two takeaways, a cafe, a florist a hardware shop and a drycleaners. The local primary schools are of a good standard and the people are generally friendly. Hither Green was featured in the Guardian Newspaper earlier in the year as a hot place to move to. I certainly enjoyed my time there. See my other maps (coming soon), for places to go out in the area.

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.48301,0.09772 My First Student House
properties.description: Posted by Ma77yWhen I lived in Plumstaed about 14 years ago, the regeneration of the Borough of Greenwich had not yet happened and so the place was run down, dirty and a bit dodgy crime wise. People have said to me that things have really imporved in the last few years though. A friend of mine had his motor bike stolen from my front garden. The gang of kids worked really well as a team and simply picked the bike up between them and made off with it across the park.

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.48798,0.05257 My Second Student House
properties.description: Posted by Ma77ySince the University of Greenwich moved its main campus into Greenwich town centre the central area of Woolwich has become a little run down. However, there is a fantastic greasy spoon cafe in the central square and a couple of "proper" boozer type pubs that can only be found in South East London. Ignore the Witherspoons pub and go for something a bit "darker". The Director General, opposite the town hall is a good starting point.

properties.name: Lat,Long: 51.55434,0.81192  My Second Family Home
properties.description: Posted by Ma77y This little village was my home from the age of about 3 to 7 or so. The place has a really quiet feel to it but the Fish and Chip shop in the village rocks. Great takeaway food. One of the newsagents used to sell sweets that are weighed out from big jars. Not sure if it is still there though.

properties.name: My Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by Ma77yThere was just the one road on and off of the Island when I lived here. A little looked down on by some other Essex residents but I love the place. My Uncle runs Canvey Motor Bodies (for all your car body and crash repair needs), which is located in Charfleets Close

properties.name: My Final Student House and Charlton Athletic FC (of course)
properties.description: Posted by Ma77y Funny place that is not really Woolwich and not really Greenwich. Has the feel of somewhere inbetween, if you know what I mean. Obviously to Football (soccer) fans, there is the slightly more important fact that Charlton Athletic\'s football ground is also at this location. Not being a footbal fan it was a little irrelevent to me but apparently I was really fortunate to have such a good view into the ground for free.
